articles.headline: Stephen Bannon Out at the White House After Turbulent Run
articles.snippet: Mr. Bannon, President Trump’s chief strategist, had clashed for months with other senior West Wing advisers and members of the president’s family.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bannon, President Trump’s chief strategist, had clashed for months with other senior West Wing advisers and members of the president’s family.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRIDGEWATER, N.J. — Stephen K. Bannon, the embattled chief strategist who helped President Trump win the 2016 election by embracing their shared nationalist impulses, departed the White House on Friday after a turbulent tenure shaping the fiery populism of the president’s first seven months in office.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Michael D. Shear and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Hard-Won Advice in Books on Aging and Elder Care
articles.snippet: Readers told our columnist what they had read and found useful, and he reports back on family conversations, division of labor, Medicaid and more.
articles.abstract: Readers told our columnist what they had read and found useful, and he reports back on family conversations, division of labor, Medicaid and more.
articles.lead_paragraph: Longevity is generally better than its alternative. But when the body or especially the mind wears out, caring for yourself or finding someone else to do it for you can impoverish you in short order.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: In Terror Attacks in Spain, a Global Community of Victims
articles.snippet: The dead and injured represented 34 nationalities, including a Belgian mother, an Italian father and an American.
articles.abstract: The dead and injured represented 34 nationalities, including a Belgian mother, an Italian father and an American.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A Belgian mother was killed while on holiday with her husband and two young sons. So was an Italian father, as he held the hand of his 5-year-old son.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle, Elisabetta Povoledo and Benoît Morenne

articles.headline: Dutch Utility Bets Its Future on an Unusual Strategy: Selling Less Power
articles.snippet: Seeking to adapt to upheaval in the energy market, Eneco is preparing for a future in which utilities provide services rather than kilowatts.
articles.abstract: Seeking to adapt to upheaval in the energy market, Eneco is preparing for a future in which utilities provide services rather than kilowatts.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — When Eneco, a major Dutch utility, tested a promising energy monitor in several dozen homes, things could not have gone much worse. The company making the devices failed to deliver enough of them, and some of those provided did not work.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Steve Bannon, Back on the Outside, Prepares His Enemies List
articles.snippet: With his ouster from the White House, Stephen K. Bannon will head back to Breitbart News, where he plans to wage war on the enemies of his nativist vision.
articles.abstract: With his ouster from the White House, Stephen K. Bannon will head back to Breitbart News, where he plans to wage war on the enemies of his nativist vision.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stephen K. Bannon has always been more comfortable when he was trying to tear down institutions — not work inside them.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: In Monument Debate, Calls for an Overdue Reckoning on Race and Southern Identity
articles.snippet: A longtime mantra used by many defenders is being undercut by the embrace of Confederate imagery by white supremacists.
articles.abstract: A longtime mantra used by many defenders is being undercut by the embrace of Confederate imagery by white supremacists.
articles.lead_paragraph: EUFAULA, Ala. — The facts of Southern history, according to Brad Griffin, are beyond dispute.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Alan Blinder and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: The Moral Voice of Corporate America
articles.snippet: C.E.O.s are speaking out on social and political issues in sometimes startling ways, recasting the role business plays in the national debate.
articles.abstract: C.E.O.s are speaking out on social and political issues in sometimes startling ways, recasting the role business plays in the national debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation has split into political tribes. The culture wars are back, waged over transgender rights and immigration. White nationalists are on the march.
articles.byline: By David Gelles

articles.headline: How to Get Away With Murder in Small-Town India
articles.snippet: In her last days in India, the Times bureau chief wrestles with a murder covered up in plain sight, and with what she is leaving behind.
articles.abstract: In her last days in India, the Times bureau chief wrestles with a murder covered up in plain sight, and with what she is leaving behind.
articles.lead_paragraph: PEEPLI KHERA, India — On my last week in India, I went to say goodbye to Jahiruddin Mewati, the chief of a small village where I had made a dozen or so reporting trips.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Charlottesville and Trump’s Response Reshape Virginia Gubernatorial Race
articles.snippet: Virginia’s gubernatorial campaign was already set to be the highest profile race of the fall. Then came the Charlottesville violence and President Trump’s response.
articles.abstract: Virginia’s gubernatorial campaign was already set to be the highest profile race of the fall. Then came the Charlottesville violence and President Trump’s response.
articles.lead_paragraph: FALLS CHURCH, Va. — The bloody white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va., has thrust race and history to the forefront of this year’s campaign for governor in Virginia, a tradition-bound state whose identity has always been rooted in a past that is as proud for some residents as it is painful for others.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Will Bannon’s White House Agenda Survive Without Him?
articles.snippet: Although Stephen K. Bannon lost as often as he won in White House debates, his departure could tip the balance on trade, climate, China and Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Although Stephen K. Bannon lost as often as he won in White House debates, his departure could tip the balance on trade, climate, China and Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his West Wing office, Stephen K. Bannon kept a chart listing trade actions — on China, steel and autos — that the Trump White House planned to roll out, week by week, through the fall. Now that Mr. Bannon, the president’s chief strategist, has been pushed out, the question is whether his agenda will be erased along with him.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: The Benefits of Standing by the President
articles.snippet: Stephen Schwarzman of Blackstone is among President Trump’s most reliable Wall Street allies. His Washington profile helped nail a big deal in Saudi Arabia.
articles.abstract: Stephen Schwarzman of Blackstone is among President Trump’s most reliable Wall Street allies. His Washington profile helped nail a big deal in Saudi Arabia.
articles.lead_paragraph: He heaped praise on Jared Kushner at a private gathering of bankers and corporate executives in December, congratulating President Trump’s son-in-law on the surprise election triumph.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Ben Protess and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Spain, a Leader in Foiling Attacks, Falls Victim to One Anyway
articles.snippet: Spain has a reputation as one of Europe’s most dogged counterterrorism operators, and officials are struggling to answer how a group of youths carried out a deadly attack.
articles.abstract: Spain has a reputation as one of Europe’s most dogged counterterrorism operators, and officials are struggling to answer how a group of youths carried out a deadly attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Spain seemed immune to the steady eruptions of Islamist violence that rocked other European countries where radicalized young men, often from poor immigrant backgrounds, carried out devastating bomb, gun or vehicular attacks.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh, Raphael Minder, Eric Schmitt and Rukmini Callimachi

articles.headline: A Deal Breaker for Trump’s Supporters? Nope. Not This Time, Either.
articles.snippet: It was a week of turmoil, but it seemed to prove an immutable rule of the Trump presidency: People see what they want to see, even if others see something very different.
articles.abstract: It was a week of turmoil, but it seemed to prove an immutable rule of the Trump presidency: People see what they want to see, even if others see something very different.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Parson Hicks, a health care finance executive who supports President Trump, this past week has felt a little like déjà vu. Mr. Trump says something. His opponents howl and then predict, with certainty, a point of no return.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Trump Settles on Afghan Strategy Expected to Raise Troop Levels
articles.snippet: President Trump will offer “a path forward for America’s engagement in Afghanistan and South Asia” in a speech on Monday that is likely to include increasing the American military presence there.
articles.abstract: President Trump will offer “a path forward for America’s engagement in Afghanistan and South Asia” in a speech on Monday that is likely to include increasing the American military presence there.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — President Trump, who has been accused by lawmakers of dragging his feet on Afghanistan, has settled on a new strategy to carry on the nearly 16-year-old conflict there, administration officials said Sunday. The move, following a detailed review, is likely to open the door to the deployment of several thousand troops.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon, Eric Schmitt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: To Sue Founder of Daily Stormer, a Neo-Nazi Site, First He Must Be Found
articles.snippet: Andrew Anglin is accused in a lawsuit of online harassment, but serving him papers has been a daunting task.
articles.abstract: Andrew Anglin is accused in a lawsuit of online harassment, but serving him papers has been a daunting task.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past five months, a group of litigants has been trying to hold Andrew Anglin, the founder of the neo-Nazi website The Daily Stormer, to account for some of his actions. It has not been easy.
articles.byline: By Nellie Bowles

articles.headline: Bannon Was Set for a Graceful Exit. Then Came Charlottesville.
articles.snippet: What was supposed to be an amicable departure for the president’s chief strategist became a messy exit after public furor over the president’s response to a race-fueled melee.
articles.abstract: What was supposed to be an amicable departure for the president’s chief strategist became a messy exit after public furor over the president’s response to a race-fueled melee.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John F. Kelly, the new White House chief of staff, told Stephen K. Bannon in late July that he needed to go: No need for it to get messy, Mr. Kelly told Mr. Bannon, according to several people with firsthand knowledge of the exchange. The two worked out a mutually amicable departure date for mid-August, with President Trump’s blessing.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Barcelona Attack Suspects Had Ties to Imam Linked to ISIS
articles.snippet: The imam, Abdelbaki Essati, brought the young men under his influence in their mountain town of Ripoll, even though few of them regularly attended mosque.
articles.abstract: The imam, Abdelbaki Essati, brought the young men under his influence in their mountain town of Ripoll, even though few of them regularly attended mosque.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Until Thursday, just hours before the Barcelona attack, many of the young men seemed to be living completely normal lives. One had slept late, his mother said. Another had worked as a waiter serving wine in a mountaintop restaurant days before. Several were eating kebabs, looking relaxed.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin, Patrick Kingsley and Palko Karasz

articles.headline: Behind the Bluster of Steve Bannon’s #War Cry
articles.snippet: Calling himself “Bannon the Barbarian,” the president’s former strategy adviser says he’s ready to “crush” his foes inside and outside the White House.
articles.abstract: Calling himself “Bannon the Barbarian,” the president’s former strategy adviser says he’s ready to “crush” his foes inside and outside the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stephen K. Bannon left the White House with a frightful howl indeed.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Crowded TV Marketplace Gets Ready for Three Tech Giants
articles.snippet: The arrival of Apple, Facebook and Google means that the hypercompetitive world of scripted TV is going to become even more ferocious.
articles.abstract: The arrival of Apple, Facebook and Google means that the hypercompetitive world of scripted TV is going to become even more ferocious.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple has more than $1 billion budgeted for original programming, Facebook wants its own version of “Scandal” and Google is ready to spend up to $3 million per episode on a drama.
articles.byline: By John Koblin

articles.headline: Lobbyist at Trump Campaign Meeting Has a Web of Russian Connections
articles.snippet: Rinat Akhmetshin, a Russian-born Washington influence peddler, has often promoted causes benefiting President Vladimir V. Putin and his allies.
articles.abstract: Rinat Akhmetshin, a Russian-born Washington influence peddler, has often promoted causes benefiting President Vladimir V. Putin and his allies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rinat Akhmetshin, a Russian immigrant who met last summer with senior Trump campaign officials, has often struck colleagues as a classic Washington mercenary — loyal to his wife, his daughter and his bank account. He avoided work that would antagonize Moscow, they suggested, only because he profited from his reputation as a man with valuable connections there.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, David D. Kirkpatrick and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: Sempra Bid Tops Buffett and Singer in Race for Energy Future
articles.snippet: The California energy company has agreed to pay $9.45 billion for the bankrupt Texas power giant, the subject of a tussle between billionaire investors.
articles.abstract: The California energy company has agreed to pay $9.45 billion for the bankrupt Texas power giant, the subject of a tussle between billionaire investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: A month and a half ago, Warren E. Buffett unveiled a $9 billion takeover bid for Energy Future Holdings, setting up a battle with a fellow billionaire, Paul E. Singer, over the bankrupt Texas utility operator.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: After Dangerous Collisions, Navy Will Pause for Safety Check
articles.snippet: A crash involving the destroyer John S. McCain near Singapore raises questions about Navy safety two months after a similar collision killed seven people.
articles.abstract: A crash involving the destroyer John S. McCain near Singapore raises questions about Navy safety two months after a similar collision killed seven people.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — United States Navy ships worldwide will suspend operations for a day or two this week to examine basic seamanship and teamwork after the second collision of a Navy destroyer with a large commercial ship in two months, the Navy’s top officer said on Monday.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Keith Bradsher
